holidays.name: National Corn on the Cob Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the classic summer favorite: corn on the cob! Whether boiled, grilled, or slathered with butter, it's all about enjoying this delicious and buttery treat.
holidays.origin: This unofficial food holiday started in the United States as a way to appreciate the humble corn cob, a staple of summertime barbecues and picnics.
holidays.funFact: Did you know Benjamin Franklin supposedly wanted the turkey to be the national bird, but he might have preferred corn as a staple? Either way, corn on the cob definitely won hearts! 🍴

holidays.name: Kiss My Docs Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration for medical professionals and patients alike to appreciate doctors who bring humor, care, and sometimes sass to medicine.
holidays.origin: Started online as a humorous nod to the stubbornness and confidence of some doctors, this day encourages light-hearted fun around medical care.
holidays.funFact: The phrase "Kiss My Docs" is a playful pun encouraging thanks (or cheekiness) towards healthcare providers, reminding us even docs have a fun side!

holidays.name: Rain Day
holidays.description: A chance to celebrate the cleansing, life-giving power of rain. Instead of hiding indoors, this day invites people to dance in the rain or appreciate the nourishment it brings.
holidays.origin: Originating in various folk traditions around the world that honor rain as a blessing for crops and life, modern Rain Day is a fun, refreshing observance.
holidays.funFact: Some studies show that rain actually releases a pleasant scent called petrichor, a favorite smell for many after a summer shower!

holidays.name: Japanese Coral Day
holidays.description: An unusual observance to raise awareness about the importance of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Japan and worldwide.
holidays.origin: This day promotes marine conservation efforts and educates on the environmental threats facing colorful coral reefs.
holidays.funFact: Coral reefs support about 25% of all marine species despite covering less than 1% of the ocean floor—talk about a busy neighborhood!
